qas.question: How did Matthew Arnold view "Culture" with?
Which two philosophers contrasted "culture" with the state of nature?
Which race was considered living "in a state of nature" by the Europeans?
"In a state of nature" was divided into two groups, what where they?
Who combined "culture" with "the state of nature"?
Which race was considered living "outside of nature" by the Europeans?
What concept contains no contrast between it?
What location is never more civilized than others?

context: Matthew Arnold contrasted "culture" with <a0_0><b4_0>anarchy<b4_0/><a0_0/>; other Europeans, following philosophers <a1_0><b5_0>Thomas Hobbes and Jean-Jacques Rousseau<b5_0/><a1_0/>, contrasted "culture" with "the state of nature". According to Hobbes and Rousseau, the <a2_0><b6_0>Native Americans<b6_0/><a2_0/> who were being conquered by Europeans from the 16th centuries on were living in a state of nature; this opposition was expressed through the contrast between <a3_0><b7_0>"civilized" and "uncivilized."<b7_0/><a3_0/> According to this way of thinking, one could classify <b8_0>some countries and nations<b8_0/> as more civilized than others and some people as more cultured than others. This contrast led to Herbert Spencer's theory of Social Darwinism and Lewis Henry Morgan's theory of cultural evolution. Just as some critics have argued that the distinction between high and low cultures is really an expression of the conflict between European elites and non-elites, some critics have argued that the distinction between civilized and uncivilized people is really an expression of the conflict between European colonial powers and their colonial subjects.
